frameDefinitions: An Agent finishes an Activity, which can no longer logically continue.
An object Theme moves in the direction of a Goal.
These words relate to the relative ordering of two events or times.
A Process comes to an end.
These are words describing situations in which a Perpetrator takes Goods from a  Victim or a Source.
A Subpart of a Time_period is picked out.
frameExamples: Jason <t>completed</t> grading the papers late Sunday night.
Some students <t>arrived</t> at the school on Sunday.
<t>After</t> she arrived , she laid out her papers on the desk.
I can't believe he <t>pickpocketed</t> my gold watch !
I nearly kicked my TV this afternoon after watching the shambolic <t><fex name='subpar'>end</fex></t> of the Austrian Grand-Prix .
listRoleDefinitions: This role identifies the <fen>Agent</fen> who has finished an <fen>Activity</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Activity</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> has finished.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Activity</fen> finishes.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Agent</fen> finishes the <fen>Activity</fen>.
<fen>Theme</fen> is the object that moves. It may be an entity that moves under its own power, but it need not be.
<fen>Goal</fen> is any expression that tells where the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up, or would end up, as a result of the motion.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when arriving occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the arriving event occurs.

The <fen>Focal_occasion</fen> is the event which is  being located in time with respect to some other event: The <fen>Focal_occasion</fen> is profiled, in contrast to the <fen>Landmark_occasion</fen>, which is backgrounded.
The <fen>Landmark_occasion</fen> is the event  with respect to which the <fen>Focal_occasion</fen> is located.
The <fen>Focal_participant</fen> is the participant in the <fen>Focal_occasion</fen> which is profiled as being in a relation of relative time to the <fen>Landmark_occasion</fen>.
Name of the event which occurs.
When the event ends.
Where the event takes place.
<fen>Perpetrator</fen> is the person (or other agent) that takes the goods away.
<fen>Victim</fen> is the person (or other sentient being or group) that owns the goods before they are taken away by the perpetrator.
<fen>Goods</fen> is anything (including labor, time, or legal rights) that can be taken away.
<fen>Source</fen> is the initial location of the goods, before they change location.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the theft occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the theft occurs.
The part of the <fen>Time_period</fen> which is profiled.
A temporal span conceived of as a whole.
This role indicates the <fen>Time</fen> that is being referred to.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Hours of eating and drinking</fex> followed the wedding ceremony.
Hours of eating and drinking followed <fex>the wedding ceremony</fex>.
Leslie stole the watch <fex>from the table</fex>.
Leslie STOLE the watch from Kim <fex>at dusk</fex>.
Leslie STOLE the watch from Kim <fex>in the park</fex>.
The findings mark the <fex>beginning</fex> of a new age of planetary science, in which 'extrasolar' planets can be directly measured and compared.
A zillion copies and clones have been made of this Russian game since it first was released in the mid <fex>80's</fex>.

passageCandidateSpans.text: the end of the first day
